sen.j: 先代当主は一色義有と思われるが継承時期や義有と義清との続柄との詳細は不詳である。
sen.e: The head clansman of the previous period is thought to have been Yoshiari ISSHIKI however, the details are unclear pertaining to the period when the succession took place and the family connection shared by Yoshiari and Yoshikiyo.

sen.j: 丹後国の守護を務めたが、若狭国武田氏の介入や守護代延永氏の下克上にあい国内は混乱した。
sen.e: He served as Governor of Tango Province however, the Takeda Clan of Wakasa Province intervened and Governor Nobunaga's clan dominated leading to chaos within the country.

He served as Governor of Tango Province but, as part of disturbances affecting the whole country, he was attacked by the Takeda Clan of Wakasa Province and the the family of Deputy Governors, the Nobunaga Clan.

He served as Shugo (Military Governor) of Tango Province but, as part of disturbances affecting the whole country, he was attacked by the Takeda clan of Wakasa Province and also suffered from Gekokujo (the revolt of vassals against their lords) of the family of Shugodai (deputy Governor), the Nobunaga clan.
sen.cmt: 一部翻訳を変更しました。

sen.j: 永正13年（1516年）から翌年にかけて同族一色九郎と争う。
sen.e: From 1516 until the following year, he battled alongside fellow clansman Kuro ISSHIKI.
From 1516 until the following year, he battled fellow clansman Kuro ISSHIKI.
From 1516 until the following year, he battled fellow clansman Kuro ISSHIKI.

sen.j: 義清は加悦城主石川直経と、九郎は守護代延永春信と結び戦いを繰り広げたが、加悦城を攻め落とされ一時没落したこともあったらしい（『東寺過去帳』）。
sen.e: Yoshikiyo, Naotsune ISHIKAWA of Kaetsu-jo Castle and Kuro joined forces and fought alongside Govenor Harunobu NOBUNAGA but apparently, Kaetsu-jo Castle came under assault and was for a time lost ("Toji Kakocho", To-ji Temple Death register).

When hostilities began, Yoshikiyo joined forces with Naotsune ISHIKAWA of Kaetsu-jo Castle and Kuro joined forces with Deputy Govenor Harunobu NOBUNAGA but apparently, Kaetsu-jo Castle came under assault and was for a time lost ("Toji Kakocho", To-ji Temple Death register).

When hostilities began, Yoshikiyo joined forces with Naotsune ISHIKAWA of Kaetsu-jo Castle and Kuro joined forces with Harunobu NOBUNAGA who was serving as Shugodai, but apparently, Kaetsu-jo Castle came under assault and was for a time lost (according to "Toji Kakocho" (To-ji Temple Death register)).

sen.j: 義清の動静は永正16年（1519年）まで判明している。
sen.e: Yoshikiyo's movements are confirmed up until 1519.
Yoshikiyo's movements are confirmed up until 1519.
Yoshikiyo's movements are confirmed up until 1519.

sen.j: 一色義幸の父（または祖父）と推定されることもある。
sen.e: Assumptions have been made about Yoshiyuki ISSHIKI's father (and grandfather).
There has been conjecture about Yoshiyuki ISSHIKI's father (and grandfather).
sen.cmt: "Assumptions have been made"→"There has been conjecture"
sen.e: There has been conjecture that Yoshikiyo ISSHIKI is Yoshiyuki ISSHIKI's father (or grandfather).
sen.cmt: 一部翻訳を修正しました。

sen.j: また、一説には土岐頼芸、次いで斎藤道三の側室となった深芳野の父ともいうが詳細不詳。
sen.e: Also, details remain unclear however, there is also a theory that Yorinori TOKI was the father of Miyoshino who was later to become the concubine of Dosan SAITO.
Also, although details remain unclear, there is a theory that his father was Yorinori TOKI, the father of Miyoshino who was later to become the concubine of Dosan SAITO.
Also, although details remain unclear, there is a theory that he is the father of Miyoshino, who first became a concubine of Yorinori TOKI and then later became that of Dosan SAITO.
sen.cmt: 一部翻訳を修正しました。

sen.j: なお、深芳野の生んだ斎藤義龍は一色左京大夫を称している。
sen.e: Furthermore, Miyoshino bore a child, Yoshitatsu SAITO, who went by the title of Sakyo-no-daibu (Chief Steward East Kyoto) Isshiki.
Furthermore, Miyoshino bore a child, Yoshitatsu SAITO, who went by the title of Sakyo-no-daibu (Chief Steward East Kyoto) Isshiki.
Furthermore, Miyoshino bore a child, Yoshitatsu SAITO, who went by the title of Isshiki Sakyo no daibu.
sen.cmt: 一部翻訳を修正しました。

sen.j: 1582年、甥で一色氏の当主であった一色義定が細川幽斎に謀殺されたため、弓木城に入って一色氏の家督を継いだ。
sen.e: In 1582, because Yoshisada ISSHIKI (nephew of the Isshiki Clan head) was willfully murdered by Yusai HOSOKAWA, Yuminoki-jo Castle was entered and he inherited the role of clan head.
In 1582, following the murder of his nephew and head of the Isshiki Clan, Yoshisada ISSHIKI, by Yusai HOSOKAWA, he moved into Yuminki-jo Castle and took over the role of clan head.
sen.cmt: "because Yoshisada ISSHIKI (nephew of the Isshiki Clan head) was willfully murdered"→"following the murder of his nephew and head of the Isshiki Clan, Yoshisada ISSHIKI""Yuminoki-jo Castle was entered and he inherited"→"he moved into Yuminki-jo Castle and took over"
sen.e: In 1582, following the murder of his nephew and head of the Isshiki clan, Yoshisada ISSHIKI, by Yusai HOSOKAWA, he moved into Yuminoki-jo Castle and took over the role of clan head.

sen.j: しかし、すぐに細川の追討軍が現れて一色軍は壊滅し、義清は細川軍の本陣に斬り込みをかけて、下宮津の海辺で壮烈な最期を遂げたという。
sen.e: However, presently Hosokawa punitive forces appeared, the Isshiki troops were annihilated and Yoshikiyo ended up being cut off by Hosokawa forces at troop HQ where it is said he made a heroic last-stand at the Shimomiyazu seashore.

However, Hosokawa punitive forces soon appeared, the Isshiki troops were annihilated and Yoshikiyo ended up being cut off at Hosokawa headquarters, where it is said he made a heroic last-stand at the Shimomiyazu seashore.

sen.e: However, Hosokawa punitive forces soon appeared, the Isshiki troops were annihilated and Yoshikiyo ended up being cut off at Hosokawa headquarters, where it is said he made a heroic last-stand at the Shimomiyazu seashore.

sen.j: 義清の死により、室町幕府における四職の一角である丹後守護家一色氏は滅亡した。
sen.e: The death of Yoshikiyo thus saw the collapse of one of the 4 branches (the Tango Governorship led by the Isshiki Clan) of the Muromachi bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun).
The death of Yoshikiyo thus saw the collapse of the Isshiki Clan, Governors of Tango, one of the 4 families the Muromachi Shogunate relied on for security.
The death of Yoshikiyo thus saw the collapse of the Isshiki clan, Governors of Tango, one of the four families the Muromachi Shogunate relied on for security.

sen.e: There is a separate branch of the Isshiki clan who served the Koga kubo (descendants of one of the Ashikaga families that held the office of the Kanto district administrator) at Satte-jo Castle.
